title: this election is not all about brexit its also a choice between state control and freedom
story: The Conservatives pledge to take us out of the European Union, the Lib Dems vow to keep us in and Labour promise to prolong the agony for another year or three.Brexit is, of course, a central issue. But something even more important is at stake.Do we want to continue to live with the free-market economy that has given us wealth unimaginable a century ago  Or do we want to be sucked backwards into the failed socialist experiment that impoverished Eastern Europe in the second half of the th century and has laid waste to Venezuela Labour has yet to produce the radical manesto Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell promised yesterday but we already know there is going to be a hike in income tax for those earning over £, a year — and probably a swingeing wealth tax, given McDonnell’s past enthusiasm for the idea.McDonnell, too, has said he would expropriate ten per cent of the shares of every British company and put them in a fund supposedly for the benefit of the workers — although when you read the small print, workers would receive a maximum of £ in idends per year, with the rest going straight into the Government’s coffers.That measly £ would do little to compensate for the collapse in value of pension funds as Labour nationalised water and electricity companies at below the market value of their shares.Many of those shares are owned by funds on which you and I rely for our retirement.The Shadow Chancellor promises that under Labour, we will only have to work a four-day, -hour week, apparently with no cut in pay. We might as well put Alice In Wonderland in charge of the economy. His sums simply don’t add up.McDonnell says he will increase the National Living Wage to £ an hour. Butlow-paid workers were stopped from working  hours a week rather than the current average of , it would mean a substantial cut in pay for millions of people.That Theresa May was unable to win an outright majority against Jeremy Corbyn and his extreme economic policies in  is as astonishing in retrospect as it was at the time. What was meant to be a coronation nearly turned into a wake. Many Conservatives fear the polls could turn sharply again.But there is scant sign Boris Johnson will repeat Mrs May’s abysmal campaign. His three months in office have brought a change in the weather. We have a Prime Minister who exudes optimism rather than a sense of defeat.While May seemed almost embarrassed to be a Conservative and tried to out-do Labour for proposing the most unappealing tax rise — the “dementia tax” — Johnson has made the case for capitalism and conservatism.The first of those, he rightly points out, pays for the public services we all value so much.He has promised to rebuild hospitals and reverse the cuts in police numbers that took place on Mrs May’s watch.He knows the way to improve the lot of people on low incomes is not to boost benefits but to increase earnings through a higher ­National Living Wage.But he also recognises middle-income groups have suffered disproportionately from the tax system in recent years and has proposed raising the threshold for the  per cent tax rate.While Corbyn and McDonnell would undermine livelihoods by cutting working hours, Johnson’s Tories will encourage us to work and to invest — in our homes, in pensions and savings. Rather than threaten businesses with confiscating shares, he promises better infrastructure, especially broadband.Boris doesn’t just want to get Brexit done, as Remainer Mrs May did.He wants to turn it to Britain’s advantage, opening our economy to the world beyond the EU, with new trade deals to bring in investment.While Mrs May created a hostile environment for migrants, Johnson has indicated a more welcoming attitude towards those who want to come to Britain to work.But more than that, it is a battle between enterprise and overbearing State control, between having the freedom to invest for your future and having your assets confiscated, between the opportunity to work and having your working hours laid down by the Government.It is a cliche to say we face the most important election in decades. But this time it really is true.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: corbyn zealots cant fit world in boxes
story: But this week, the world received a rare bit of sanity from a surprising source.Despite being something of a messianic figure among the “progressive” young, Barack Obama attacked the very culture they aspire to.In an interview for his Obama Foundation’s annual summit in Chicago on Tuesday, he laid into “wokeness” and young people who are obsessed with “purity”.Obama told his audience: “I get a sense among certain young people on social media that the way of making change is to be as judgemental as possible about other people.”Hear, bloody, hear.This was not the only important segment of his talk, which contained huge lessons for whippersnappers.He also said, “the world is messy, there are ambiguities” and, “people who do really good stuff have flaws”.Obama’s address could not have come at a more important time, particularly given the major culture wars that are being fought in the West.Something that is completely absent from our debates, and arguably driving new tensions, is the idea that le is “messy”, as Obama says, and requires compromise.Instead, we are seeing activists treat issues asthey can be put in neat little boxes — with a right and wrong answer.This is part of the reason why university campuses have become such toxic places.They are incubators for hysteria, where students act like religious zealots, banning celebrated academics such as Germaine Greer for not spouting their approved doctrines.Twitter, too, is being used to hound others for having “incorrect” views, with pile-ons and clips circulated of the “blasphemous”.Say something “wrong” and you are “cancelled”. No debate.This extremism is feeding into real-le events, including the campaign for next month’s General Election. Just look at the Labour Party and its leader Jeremy Corbyn.Despite presenting himself as a kind and compassionate old bean, Corbyn and most MPs in the current Labour Party thrive on presenting society as a fight between “good” and “evil”, the “few” and “many”, with people like bankers and Tories in the latter group.At every chance they demonise anyone who strays from the progressive orthodoxy.Labour’s shouty MP David Lammy even took this philosophy so far as to compare Jacob Rees-Mogg’s hard Brexit European Research Group to “Nazis” and “apartheid”.In reality, they are simply politicians who have dferent views to him.But such extreme rhetoric has become normalised among Labour. You are either on their side of the argument, or you are a fascist.Labour’s polarised world view is encapsulated in its utterly bonkers set of policies.Any sensible government knows that economic reform takes time, and is often about compromise and improving existing structures.But Labour wants to tear everything down and start again, with private schools being top of the list — no doubt because MPs have a vendetta against Etonians.Corbyn also wants to abolish Universal Credit, despite having no tangible plan for its replacement.Universal Credit is the perfect example of where Labour goes wrong. The system has had teething issues but the answer is not to burn it down, it is to make slow improvements.There are other huge, sweeping pledges the party has made, such as nationalising the railways, water, energy and mail, seizing a ten per cent stake in every private company with more than  staff and having a target of net zero for carbon emissions by .Experts have suggested this could lead to meat being rationed, cars confiscated and the wholesale closure of industries .Who cares, though,it gets Labour in charge!Much of the reason Labour has set upon these radical policies is because shaking up the system is always incredibly exciting for the young, particularlyit looks like it might bring about a few freebies.And let’s face it, it is no surprise that millennials and their younger counterparts can be enticed.They have had a rough ride since the  financial crisis, absorbing the shock of the recession and being decades away from home ownership.It is no wonder they think socialism is the answer, especially as it plays into the woke mindset of there being simple, binary solutions to everything.This is why it is so important that young people actually take on what Obama was saying about the world.The Government has to make large numbers of deeply complex decisions, where there cannot always be winners.Almost always someone will lose out in the intricate interplay that is political decision-making.There needs to be more acceptance of a Margaret Thatcher-style realism: That le is not fair.That is something youngsters do not seem to grasp these days, believing equalities can be remedied with the magic wand of socialism.Strong, long-lasting policies do not make sexy soundbites like “For the many”, nor can they be advertised in protests outside Parliament Square. Like Obama said, the world is messy.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bacon shortage african swine fever spreading
story: The speed at which the deadly animal virus has been spreading across Asia has taken policy makers by surprise. Globally, it has been found in  countries, including Poland, Russia, South Korea and the Philippines, killing hundreds of million pigs, while reshaping global meat and feed markets.But Monique Eloit, who heads the World Organisation for Animal Health , said: The risk exists for ALL countries, whether they are geographically close or geographically distant because there is a multitude of potential sources of contamination.We are really facing a threat that is global. While African swine fever is not harmful to humans, it can be transmitted by a tourist bringing back a ham or sausage sandwich from a contaminated country.Should infected pork, for example, but thrown in the bin it could be reused by farmers to feed their pigs who will almost certainly diethey contract it.  China, the world’s largest producer of pork, has seen a  per cent reduction in its hog population due to swine fever. And it is feared should the disease turn into a pandemic a similar reduction would be reflected globally.  The disease has spread rapidly to several countries in Southeast Asia including Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Korea and the Philippines and more countries are likely to be hit in the coming months.This outbreak of the virus is believed to have originated from Africa and then spread to Georgia through the transportation of pig products.The spread was believed to have been worsened by wild boars. Insects including ticks may also be responsible.The virus can survive after the animal has died, it can live on in processed meat for up to a few months and in frozen meat for up several years.Currently the disease cannot be passed onto humans, although there are concerns about future mutations potentially affecting mankind.US pork sales to bacon blighted China have doubled, while European pork prices have reached a six-year high.OIE Vice-president Dr Mark Schipp said the swine fever was the biggest threat to any commercial livestock of our generation.But take a look at what this virus is doing around the globe today. And then look at the way goods and people travel.This would have a devastating effect on our industry. It’s the nastiest disease we have on the planet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gritty pics offer glimpse into life on londons high rise council estates
story: Heaving concrete towers erupt into the sky from the tarmac below in images proudly displaying the brutalist architecture of the post war period.Most of the historical Council estates have been built from the fties, following the Socialist plan of providing modern housing to low income families.It was from here that the misguided idea of streets in the sky was born.The images capture not just the buildings, but the people who live in these tenement blocks that sprung up around the capital during the s and s.Huge towers shot up on the outskirts of the city filled with people uprooted from the centre of town where they could no longer afford to live.Italian snapper Marco Sconocchia, who took the photos for an exhibition titled Utopia, said he was inspired to move from his native Turin to England out of a fascination with the British working classes.He said: I was fascinated by the culture that came from the English working classes, especially bands like Oasis and The Stone Roses.So when I came here in , I suppose I gravitated towards those sort of places. That’s where I liked to have a drink, have a pork pie. I like the people there. They talk to you. They don’t have agendas.”Marco added that when he asked subjectshe could take their picture, they looked at him like he was a lunatic.The photographer added: I wanted to get the brutality and the beauty. These two things, they coexist, not just in London high-rises but everywhere.That’s the human condition. That’s part of the point.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: entitled buffon chippy ex student no10
story: Surely we deserve better than a bumptious, entitled ­buffoon and a chippy ex- student inhabiting No . Are these two really the brightest and the best  Obviously not. But with politics becoming ever more isive and toxic, they are all we have left.Let’s be honest. What normal human being would want to be part of such a cesspit  As we are all well aware, the past three years have seen a constipated parliament unable, or unwilling, to sort out Brexit, forcing us all into a nightmarish version of Groundhog Day.I believe the idea of a European referendum was the height of stupidity by a spooked David Cameron who wanted to neuter Nigel Farage. When the nation voted Leave, Cameron was the first to abandon ship.Never mind “women and children first”. He was rowing away from a Titanic mess in a leboat stuffed with like-minded, snivelling clowns, leaving poor Theresa May behind playing an out-of-tune piano with the rest of the ship’s doomed orchestra. Mrs May foolishly called an election that was a personal disaster, then was worn down until she had to step aside.Boris Johnson thought he could bluster and blag his way to a solution and promised we would exit the EU a couple of days ago, on Halloween. For all his blather about “dying in a ditch”, he couldn’t deliver.So here we are, facing a pre-Christmas election at a time when distrust of politicians has never been higher and our expectations have been never lower. It is easy to dismiss the whole bloody lot of them as a waste of time.But there ARE some decent MPs who want to make a dference. Sadly, some are unwilling to put up with the scrutiny and vilication the job now entails and many are heading out the door.Female MPs, in particular, have been subjected to online abuse that chills the blood. As well as death threats, they have had to deal with vile monsters threatening rape and other violent attacks. It’s horric to have to cope with such hideous abuse on a daily basis. I can’t blame them for quitting in despair.Their fears are real. We saw that with the tragic murder of MP Jo Cox in . She was a we and mother who wanted to make the world a better place and do the best possible job for her constituents. It’s a real pity the MPs now calling it a day are mainly moderates who were calm ­voices of reason amid all the shrieking and howling from extremists on both sides of the political ide.Heidi Allen, a Tory who joined the Lib Dems, can no longer cope with the “nastiness and intimidation” which has become the norm in Parliament. Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan is leaving because the abuse towards her has had a “clear impact” on her ­family.The Tory and the Labour leaderships should hang their heads in shame at allowing such an appalling situation to develop. title: boris centre of attention may
story: “I feel confident, but then I felt confident in ,” one leading Cabinet Minister tells me.There is a Tory fear that ­history could repeat itself — that Jeremy Corbyn could surge again and an election designed to deliver a majority for Brexit could once more lead to a hung Parliament. But oddly,  is one of the things that mean the Tories might win that majority this time round. They are determined not to make the same mistakes again. As one senior party figure puts it: “We screwed it up once. We’re not going to do that again.”When Chancellor Sajid Javid spoke to Tory MPs on Wednesday night, he reassured them that “this campaign will not be like last time”. He described Theresa May’s  effort as “the most incompetent election campaign in modern times”.In , the Tories assumed that their chunky poll lead would easily translate into a big majority. There was a complacency and cockiness about their campaign. There was no ­rationale for why Mrs May was going back on her pledge not to have an election and a belief that the Tories could use that lead to win a mandate for almost anything.This time round, the Tories are being much more cautious. The groundwork has been laid for this campaign. Conservative Campaign HQ has been getting election-ready for months. The Tories have heavy-hitters ready to join their ­campaign team, including Paul Stephenson, one of the key ­figures from Vote Leave’s  victory. In , Mrs May took her own party machine by ­surprise with her decision to go to the country.In another dference with the ex-PM, Boris Johnson has a clear argument for why an ­election is needed — the only thing this Parliament is capable of on Brexit is delay. It is hard to see how anyone who wants Brexit and has seen what has happened since the  election could disagree with that.This Tory desire not to screw up will also lead to more ­discipline. This time, the ­manesto will be a cautious document, not an attempt to gain a mandate for a series of deeply unpopular reforms. The fact that everyone knows this election will be close helps the Tories too. There’ll be much more scrutiny of what a Corbyn premiership would mean than there was in .Cabinet Ministers believe that the prospect of a Labour SNP deal which would see Nicola Sturgeon’s Scottish Nationalists help Corbyn into Downing Street in exchange for another independence referendum is already cutting through, and particularly in Scotland, where the Tories are increasingly ­confident they can limit their losses to five seats or fewer.But perhaps the biggest dference from  is between Johnson and May. May had never done a ­national campaign before, she disliked big events and preferred going door to door. Boris, by contrast, is a showman who has already ­successfully fronted one nationwide effort, the  referendum. Boris knows how to make himself the centre of attention in a way Mrs May never did.As one Cabinet minister puts it: “Boris is ­capable of stealing the oxygen from all the other candidates.”The most signicant threat to the Tories is pro-Remain tactical voting. The big question, frets one Cabinet minister, is whether Labour and the Lib Dems end up splitting the ­centre-left vote and letting the Tories win — as happened with Labour and the SDP in  — or whether there is anti-Tory voting that condemns scores of previously safe Tory MPs to defeat — as happened in .Butthe Tories avoid the pitfalls of , then even from a much less promising starting position they should be able to win a majority.THIS election will see the first ever head-to-head televised leaders’ debate between the two big parties. On November , Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson will clash in primetime on ITV. Both Labour and the Tories think they will benefit from this one-on-one format.On the Labour side, they hope that it helps them unite the anti-Tory vote behind Corbyn. The Tories think the question of who you want to be Prime Minister – Johnson or Corbyn – favours them.During the  campaign, Theresa May lost her lead on this question. But right now, Boris Johnson has a -point advantage over Corbyn. If he can maintain anything like this margin, he’ll still be in No  come Christmas.Downing Street also thinks that making this election a forced choice between a Tory government and a Labour government works to their benefit. Polling for Conservative Campaign HQ shows that half of voters want the Tories in government in some way, compared to just over a quarter for Labour.They calculate that making the election a choice between Johnson and Corbyn helps them squeeze the Brexit Party vote down – something which is particularly important given Nigel Farage’s determination to put up candidates right across the country.Influential Tories are also worried thatthe Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson turns in a barnstorming performance, her party could threaten the Tories in their shire seats.Johnson himself will not do the seven-way debate between the party leaders. The Tories are keen to downplay the importance of this event. I’m told they are considering sending Sajid Javid, Michael Gove, Priti Patel or Rishi Sunak.THE “moratorium” announced on fracking today is a sign of the Tories’ safety-first approach going into this election. They want to close down issues that could cost them seats.One minister defends the decision to abandon the effort to improve the UK’s energy security by saying: “The reality is, it wasn’t happening.”But a bigger factor was their desire not to go into the election with this as a potential vulnerability.I understand that, in stark contrast to , the manesto will be a cautious document designed to prevent handing ammunition to Labour.AT CABINET on Tuesday, Boris Johnson called the Scottish Secretary Alister Jack to speak.An embarrassed Jack explained that he wasn’t actually trying to get in, to which Johnson replied he thought his hand was up.Jack, a multi-millionaire who owns a large farm, then quipped to laughter: “That’s why my farm manager doesn’t let me go to auctions.”THE Tories are planning to accuse Labour of staging a massive raid on the pension pots of million voters.This would hurt the .million who contribute to a private ­pension. Afterwards, one Tory told me Javid’s message was clear: “Labour are coming after your money.”I understand the Tories are also preparing a “tax bombshell” attack on Corbyn.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The movie hunk also revealed he and fellow environmental campaigner Greta, , have “made a commitment to support one another”.The Oscar winning actor – regularly slammed for his use of private jets despite backing environmental causes - said it was an “honour” to speak with the Swedish climate activist.In an Instagram post Leo said he hopes Gretas message is “a wake-up call to world leaders” and told how she makes him “optimistic about what the future holds”.It comes as the schoolgirl launched a bid for help on social media to cross the Atlantic to Spain for the United Nations COP climate conference.The major meeting of world leaders was supposed to be taking place in December in Chile.But protests have been taking place there against the government which has led to serious trouble in the streets.Madrid has now offered to host the summit and it will be considered by the UNs climate body next week.In September DiCaprio came out in support of Greta at a New York conference.And he recently pledged million towards combating the Amazon rain forest fires to protect the lungs of the planet.The Hollywood heavyweight made the announcement through his environmental foundation Earth Alliance.But he is regularly slammed for splurging on private jets and in  emails hacked from film studio Sony showed it was revealed he took six private flights in just six weeks which cost £,.Teenage stigma Greta first hit the headlines in  when she inspired international youth climate strikes and spoke at the Extinction Rebellion protests before she met UK politicians.She shot to fame as the poster-girl for climate change awareness after a picture of her “school strike for climate change” was posted on Facebook by Swedish eco-warrior, Ingmar Rentzhog.Her strike inspired tens of thousands of students from around the world to join her #FridaysforFuture demonstrations - skipping school every Friday to protest climate change.Her work in the UK has included meeting politicians from across the spectrum in Westminster as the Extinction Rebellion protests took place outside.She told them her future and those of other young people had been sold adding: We probably dont even have a future any more.The Swedish teenager grabbed the worlds attention when she staged a School Strike for Climate in front of the Swedish Parliament in August .Greta was driven to take action by a record heatwave in northern Europe and forest fires that ravaged swathes of Swedish land up to the Arctic.The teenager said she is inspired by US civil rights activist Rosa Parks, who refused to give up her seat to a white passenger on a racially segregated bus.I learned she was an introvert, and Im also an introvert, she said.Speaking at the Global Citizen Festival DiCaprio said: Its become clear that our political leaders have failed to live up to promises that we celebrated that day.Our future is being gambled away, and our leaders, those whom we entrust to protect us and set the example, are either failing to stop these dangerous trends or, in some cases, denying the very science of this climate catastrophe.Its not the first time DiCaprio has spoken out against Trump.In  he chastised him for ignoring facts and truths and modern science.A carbon-neutral future is the only way we will inherit a planet capable of sustaining le on Earth as we know it.

title: books for schools launch campaign
story: Some , schools in England, Wales and Northern Ireland will get the chance to get a free pack of books worth more than £. It is simple to get involved. Primary schools can register now at thesun booksforschools until Friday, November . On Saturday, November , we will start printing tokens in the paper for you to collect.Head teacher Frances Ward said: “The Sun’s free books have really caught the children’s imaginations. We can’t wait to start collecting tokens.”To mark the launch, we also speak to top authors, including Michael Morpurgo, about their love for books.  So, what are you waiting for  Join us.. Help your school collect , tokens from The Sun and The Sun on Sunday between Saturday, November , , and Saturday, January , . Once your school has , tokens, they will need tothem by Saturday, February , . Your school will receive the books in March “Stories give us knowledge and understanding. They teach us about our place in the world and we learn what happened in the past and how we can do better in the future. All of those lessons come from books. The gt of reading is the greatest enabling thing we can give a child. So, the fact that the Sun is giving children from all kinds of backgrounds more books is incredible.”The best-selling author, , who has written more than  books, remains one of the hardest-working writers around. He says: “I can’t see a time when I’ll ever stop writing.”Although we have more children’s authors than ever before, Michael says we have a problem. There are thousands of kids who  don’t enjoy reading. The former children’s laureate  says: “It could be for any reason. Perhaps there aren’t enough books at home, or the child hasn’t been read to enough.“Or they don’t have access to a decent library.  Or perhaps the adults in their le don’t have enough enthusiasm for books to make it a priority. Whatever the reason, it’s an issue. It takes one book to change everything. Whether it’s a story by Judith Kerr, David Walliams or one of my books, a child engages in a book they will read another one. But the books have to be there in the first place.Michael’s passion for books is obvious and he believes that, in the digital world, many of us have become lazier when it comes to  teaching children. He says: “Technology is overwhelming everything. It is so much easier to give a child an electronic device. Just by pressing a button, they are entertained without any parental or teaching involvement. But reading is about communicating with other people. And being read to by somebody who cares is so important for children.”The former primary school teacher  from Devon   adds: “Children have the right to have a great school library,   great parents and  great teachers. For a child to get lost in a book they must enjoy it. You will only read stories and poems for pleasureyou’re actually enjoying them. The minute you turn stories into comprehension and tests you wreck the whole thing.”Michael realises that boys in particular can struggle to enjoy reading as they get older, as he also stopped enjoying books as a lad. He says: “As a young boy, I loved Enid Blyton’s stories until I was eight and wanted to turn the page. After that age, there were too many school tests and so much pressure to be able to recite poems word-for-word, it took all of the joy out of stories for me. It wasn’t until I was ten and I read Treasure Island, by Robert Louis Stevenson, that I was hooked again.”In , Michael was awarded a knighthood for services to literature and charity. He remains a passionate ambassador for children’s books and believes that it is through literature that we can talk about sensitive subjects.He says: “The British have always been incredible storytellers and historically we do it very well. If we are to create literary adults who continue to write incredible stories, we need to create literary children. It’s the only way.”IN our tech-heavy world, it has never been more important to remember the huge part books play in a child’s le, says  Dame Jacqueline Wilson. The  Tracy Beaker author, who is backing The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign,  believes we need to  do everything we can to share the love of books.The former children’s laureate, , says: “Campaigns such as this show people care passionately about the importance of books and children reading. Hopefully, it will resonate with  people and act as a ripple-on-a-pond effect. In this day and age, where it is rare for a school to have its own library and librarian, it is  easy to forget about the part the books can play in a child’s le.“Many children grow up in warm, cosy homes and have lots of lovely outings and the latest devices. Although most parents want their child to read well, it seems as though reading together can sometimes be overlooked and not regarded as important. Even at my age, I can’t stop buying books. I’m not sure I’ll  even have enough time to read all of the books I’ve got.”Jacqueline has written an astonishing  novels, including the Tracy Beaker series which was turned into a popular television series for CBBC. She has never been one to shy away from writing about tough subjects such as adoption, orce and mental illness. She says: “I’m very  evangelical about the importance of sharing books with children so that they can learn that stories equal joy from a young age.“If we can encourage that love of books  when young, that will hopefully follow a child for their whole le. The love of stories often  comes after you’ve learnt the mechanics of how to read. That’s when you can become totally absorbed in a story.  Just ten minutes a day of reading a book to a child can make such a huge dference.“Even as a child becomes older, and can read themselves, it’s still great to share books together. I think it’s wonderful when unlikely people such as sportsmen, actresses and musicians talk about how much they love reading and write books. They have a particular power to be able to connect with children who might not relate to nerdy writers like me.“As a child, I adored What Katy Did, and Ballet Shoes by Noel Streatfeild.  I totally immersed myself in that world. I imagined I was going to stage school and my bedroom slippers were ballet shoes.” All I ever wanted to do was write stories and I wrote my first ‘novel’ when I was nine. To this day, books are still my passion.“We talk about the huge benefits for children when reading a story, but it’s such a treat for an adult to read to a child. I know that some parents are shy about reading aloud, but they don’t need to be. Children don’t mindwords are fluffed or mispronounced. Some children  struggle to sit still and listen to a story, which can make it become a chore.“However, parents need to allow the child to do what they need to do in order to be comfortable. They don’t need to sit still, quiet as a mouse, and listen. If they’re happy playing with their Lego or colouring, then let them do that and just read to them. It’s similar to an adult listening to the radio or a podcast. For some children, listening like that is much more enjoyable. Reading for pleasure is truly wonderful, it would be a very sad day indeedwe stopped.”For more information, pick up The Sun.Later this month we’ll start printing tokens in the paper for schools and parents to collect.Once they reach the target, we’ll send out a bumper pack of  Collins Big Cat books, suitable for kids in Reception and Year .Schools can register at thesun booksforschoolsEVERYBODY should have access to books because they help you achieve your dreams, says author Holly Smale. The writer of the hit Geek Girl novel series for teens is backing The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign. Holly, , admits she was obsessed with books from early childhood and where other kids had a favourite teddy, Holly would clutch her copy of Enid Blyton’s The Faraway Tree and take it wherever she went.Holly, from Hertfordshire, says: “Ever since I was a small child I knew I wanted to write stories and I pursued the dream relentlessly. I wouldn’t have achieved my le’s ambitionI wasn’t able to read as often as I wanted to.”As a little girl, Holly was taken to the library with her sister every week. She says: “We didn’t have any money for books and I read so many that my mum couldn’t keep up with me. We went to the library every Saturday and I would take the maximum amount of books, I think it was ten, every single time. My library card felt as though it was a special key which meant I could access anything.“My poor mum would stagger home under the weight of all our books then we’d be back again the following weekend. My little sister was very loyal to one particular book and borrowed Dogger by Shirley Hughes every week. My parents accepted my obsession with reading and the fact I’d hold a book with one hand while eating with the other. By the time I started school I could read and was lucky that there was a whole new selection of books for me. I still use libraries to this day.”School was tricky for Holly. She was badly bullied but was able to channel the experience into Harriet Manners, the heroine of her award-winning young adult novels. She says: “Books have always been there for me through good times and bad times. On a bad day at school, I’d hide in my bedroom and read Anne Of Green Gables. Every book you read becomes a part of you.”There are depressing statistics about the drop in children reading for pleasure, but Holly believes it’s about finding the right story. She says: When I was a girl, Netflix and YouTube didn’t exist. On long, boring days, it was natural to lose yourself in a book, but nowadays youngsters have more choice on how to spend their time.“Sadly, I don’t have time to read ten books a week any more but I usually have two on the go. There are times when I need to turn the telly off or come back earlier from the pub to finish a book. But losing myself in a great story reminds me I’m doing what I love . . . I’ve got the le I wanted as a kid.”IT’S simple to start. All primary schools need to do is visit thesun booksforschools before Friday, November .For more information, pick up The Sun.Later this month we’ll start printing tokens in the paper for schools and parents to collect.Once they reach the target, we’ll send out a bumper pack of  Collins Big Cat books, suitable for kids in Reception and Year .Schools can register at thesun booksforschoolsOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: general election voting twice register bournemouth university student
story: ‘Lucy’, , is said to be studying at Bournemouth University and her Twitter message has exposed the weaknesses of the country’s electoral system.The student vote could become a key factor in the outcome of December’s general election with any potential infringements on the regulations possibly impacting on the final result.Her Twitter message said: “I have just re-registered for both my hometown AND UNI address… in under  seconds! If you live at a second address… ADD it to the register and you can vote TWICE. Register twice. Be brave.”‘Lucy’, who has been given an alias, registered to vote both at her university address and her parents’ home in a suburb of Birmingham – which she is entitled to do under the law.However the controversy arises not with her registering twice but with her encouragement of voting twice, which would be an illegal act.Under electoral rules you can only cast one vote in just one constituency, breaking that rule could see you face a £, fine.When contacted by the Daily Mail, ‘Lucy’s’ father, , took a dim view of his daughter’s actions.He said: “Oh, interesting, she shouldn’t be doing that. I’ll be having a word with her to tell her to do something about this. I definitely don’t condone this at all. I’ll be on the phone to her very shortly.”In the previous general election in  Jeremy Corbyn-backing students in places such as Canterbury and Lincoln were blamed for causing political upsets where Conservative victories had been predicted.In Canterbury, which had been a solid Tory seat for decades, Labour took the seat after it saw its share of the vote nearly double to  per cent.In Lincoln, which has a student population of around ,, saw Labour’s share of the vote rise by . per cent.In two electoral wards, where most of the students in Lincoln live, the turnout for polling was said to have jumped by  per cent or more.At the time the University of Lincoln authorities told the former Tory MP Karl McCartney, that it would be normal for only - per cent of students registered to vote at one hall of residence, The Junxion, to turn up to do so, because many would have already left the city for the summer break.But  per cent of registered students from the hall of residence voted, with none of their votes cast by proxy or by post.Mr McCartney, who is hoping to regain his seat at the Tory candidate, told the Mail he suspected he lost his seat due to plans orchestrated by the Labour group Momentum.Following the  he claims to have discovered two students from The Junxion pictured together in Greece on social media on the election day, although both were listed in polling records to have voted in person in Lincoln.Mr McCartney said: ‘I am not saying these two students were at fault.“But were their polling cards pinched from the hall of residence after they left to go abroad  Did the stealing of polling cards of absent students happen multiple times at The Junxion “Did student activists find the polling cards lying around and go to vote, pretending to be someone  ”Mr McCartney also claimed five Lincoln constituents were prevented from voting saying that when they got to their polling station at around mid-morning, someone had already used their name and address to vote.He said: “I am told that the five had all been visited on their doorsteps by Momentum’s Labour canvassers in the previous few days.“The constituents had told the Labour activists that they were not going to vote, or did not normally vote, but later changed their minds.”Mr McCartney said he had reported his concerns to the Electoral Commission but no action was ever taken.“His claims smack of someone grasping for excuses for their failure.Momentum members put in hard, honest work to secure a Labour MP in Lincoln and we deny any allegations of wrongdoing.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionAsh Sarkar: Stop poor people being punished for crimes of the richUnless we take the opportunity to vote Labour’s jobs-first green plan into power, we’ll end up with a Tory reaction to the climate emergency which is just like their response to the financial crash...ShareCommentsByAsh Sarkar:,  NOV NewsopinionA polar bear managed to get on one of the last ice floes floating in the Arctic sea "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI can’t stand middle-class hippies. I get that they’re an important part of the social ecology, like mushrooms or something. But I’ve got a rare-but-very-real deathly allergy to drum circles. Every time I meet a white guy with dreadlocks, I break out in hives. And, fundamentally, I just don’t understand why you would actively make the choice to live a le of bland food and occasional washing when you can plainly afford not to. As much as I rate Extinction Rebellion for pushing climate change to the top of the political agenda, it’s dropped some absolute clangers when it comes to class. In a doomed attempt to target the wealthy bankers of Canary Wharf, an XR affinity group shut down a DLR train in Newham, the borough with the highest percentage of low-paid employees in London. Extinction Rebellion soon admitted this tactic was a mistake.    It’s hard to feel like rising sea levels and polar bears stranded on ice floes are top priority when you’re drowning in debt and stuck in a dreadful job. The fact is, making the lives of poor people worse is the opposite of climate justice. A decade of public service cuts and the worst squeeze on wages since the Napoleonic Wars didn’t magically yank carbon out of the atmosphere. The unfair system that saw the incomes of the country’s richest , people go up by % over the last  years while real wages fell for the rest of us is the same system that’s polluting our planet for profit. It doesn’t have to be this way. This weekend Labour is launching its policy agenda for a Green Industrial Revolution. And it’s about as far from climate austerity as you can get. Spurred into action by an influx of young and environmentally conscious activists into the Labour Party, Corbyn’s team have already pledged  measures to make our energy system carbon-neutral by the s. With damp homes and households suffering from fuel poverty getting first dibs, Labour wants houses in the UK to be properly insulated and fitted with double-glazing.

story: NewsCouple didnt recognise their own babies after twins born dangerously prematureThe twins were born weighing less than lb each but were miraculously saved due to the phenomenal work by hospital staffShareCommentsBySam Truelove:,  NOV NewsTeddy and Sofia were born weighing less than a tin of bins "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNewborn twins who were born nearly four months premature - weighing less than a tin of bins - have made a miraculous recovery. Candice Jardine, , and Tom Dallinger,  couldnapost recognise their tiny babies after they were born weighing less than lb each.The couple had to have their twins pointed out to them by hospital staff as they fought for their lives in an incubator, the Liverpool Echo reports.Candice and Tom, from Wallasey, Wirral rushed to Arrowe Park Hospital when Candice started feeling pains just over half way through her pregnancy. Doctors told the expecting mum she was in labour and a day later she gave birth to their tiny twins Teddy and Sofia.    But it wasnapost the amazing moment Candice had envisaged. There was no initial hold your baby, bond with your baby, enjoy the moment that youaposve waited for for nine months, she said. We didnapost even know which babies were ours, we had to be shown which incubators our babies were in and then you look at them through a glass box. Teddy and Sofia were transferred to the Neonatal Unit at Wirral Women and Children’s Hospital for specialist intensive care. When they first visited them, Candice and Tom had to have their twins pointed out to them by staff. It was a painful process for the young family, with the twins spending two and a half months in hospital fighting for their lives. They were saved due to the phenomenal staff at the neonatal unit, Tom said.    He said: The care, the staff, was phenomenal. They went out of their way to make us, as parents, feel comfortable. Anything we needed they were there, in terms of personal and emotional support they went out of their way to make sure we were ok. We canapost thank them enough. Gorgeous twins Teddy and Sofia are now at home with their parents and growing up well. There are plans to refurbish and expand the Neonatal Unit at Wirral Women and Children’s Hospital in the future, providing a better space for sick babies to be cared for. Wirral University Teaching Hospital Charity’s ‘Tiny Stars’ appeal is aiming to raise £. million over the next three years to fund the project. Dr Sanjeev Rath, Neonatal Consultant at Wirral University Teaching Hospital, said: We provide intensive care to the most vulnerable babies who are very sick.  Our aim is to get a unit with adequate space for each baby and their family which will also help with infection control.”

title: family six living daily nightmare
story: NewsFamily of six living daily nightmare stuck in one filthy room in shared houseCraig Simmonds and Roxanne Stamford have been forced to move their family around caravans, hotels and temporary accommodation after falling into the gaps with local authoritiesShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe family say they are living a daily nightmare"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family of six say they are aposliving a daily nightmareapos, forced to stay in one filthy room of a shared house. Craig Simmonds and Roxanne Stamford, who have one disabled child and a young baby, are bringing up their family in the tiny room - which had blood stains on the bedding and mice droppings on the carpet. The couple told to Bristol Live they had to threaten Bristol City Council with an emergency court injunction just to get a room for the night. The family said they have fallen into the gaps, with two local authorities - Bristol and Cornwall Council - both attempting to deny they are responsible for housing them. Over the last few months, they say they have been moved around constantly, from a caravan in Cornwall to hotels and temporary accommodation until they ended up in a House of Multiple Occupancy in Southville, Bristol. Craig and Roxanne arrived at the room in Southville in the middle of October, after four days in an emergency tourist holiday let AirBnB in the city centre. They found the accommodation had a double bed and a bunk bed.The bedding was blood-stained, the room and the tiny en-suite shower-room was filthy, with mouse droppings evident and a dirty carpet, toilet and cooking area. The next day, after sending images of the state of the place to Bristol City Council, an emergency ‘deep clean’ was arranged.    And there, the family of six have remained, waiting in limbo while two local authorities  miles apart argue the other is responsible for housing them. The couple’s ordeal began last year when Roxanne suffered from serious post-natal depression and other mental health issues following the birth of her youngest child, Aimee. Roxanne and Craig lived in Cornwall, where Craig worked long hours as a chef.Roxanne’s illness meant he kept having to take time off work to care for her and his children, and so he lost his job, and the couple fell into rent arrears on their council house in Camborne. They were eventually evicted by Cornwall Council on May  this year, and have not had a permanent home since. Craig is born and bred in Bristol.When he was nine, escaping an abusive relationship, his mum moved the family to Cornwall, where he then lived. He grew up, met Roxanne, started a family and his mum Lou was a huge help as the couple - at that point - had three children, Catelynn, Freddie and Harry. Freddie, particularly, needed more help - he has a range of special needs, including cerebral palsy, and has to have his legs rubbed vigorously after any exercise. But three years ago, Lou ‘retired’ back to her native South Bristol, moving into an over-s flat in Stockwood, and when Aimee arrived last year, Craig and Roxanne struggled on their own. So when they were evicted by Cornwall Council on May , the couple didn’t know where  to go, but to put all their belongings into a family member’s car, and drive up the M to Bristol. “I didn’t want the kids to see the bailfs actually come and chuck us out, I couldn’t bear that to happen,” said Roxanne, who is pregnant. “So I left the keys with a neighbour and we left the day before, on April , before the bailfs came.” They squeezed in to Lou’s flat for a couple of nights, and presented themselves at  Temple Street, Bristol City Council’s housing department headquarters.   The couple were put into a three-bed house, albeit temporarily, in Bedminster.The three older children were enrolled into their local primary school and as a skilled chef, Craig got a job quickly at a local pub. “Everything was sorted, or seemed to be,” said Craig. “The school was amazing, the kids settled in really well, they loved going to school, and I got a job. The house was nice, and I thought we would be ok.” But behind the scenes, it appears a conflict was brewing between Bristol City Council and Cornwall Council. As the family went through the process of applying for more permanent housing, they were told there was a problem. Craig’s ‘local links’ didn’t meet the criteria. He hadn’t been an adult in Bristol. He and his family hadn’t lived in Bristol for more than six months.  His family link to his mum didn’t count either - any family member has to have lived in Bristol for five years for that to count, and Lou only moved back to the city three years ago. Bristol is a city still in the grips of a housing crisis, despite new homes being built in their hundreds.There are , people on the housing waiting list, and  families in temporary accommodation. As the summer began, the family were told they would have to go back to Cornwall, and present themselves as homeless there, not in Bristol. It was Harry’s sixth birthday, the day the children were taken out of Parson Street School and driven back down the M to be put into a single room in a shared house in Newquay. “It was awful. At am there were people drunk or on drugs, banging on the door, shouting they were going to kill us. The children were terried,” said Craig.    Cornwall Council kept moving them around places like that, including for a spell, into a caravan.By mid-August, the new school year was looming and Roxanne was desperate to provide some stability for her children. “Trying to get the kids into school was an absolute nightmare. Cornwall Council told us they would have to go to school, but allocated the three of them three dferent schools, which was just impossible,” said Craig. Then, Craig said Cornwall Council told them their efforts to find them a home had failed, and hit them with another bombshell. “They told us we had made ourselves intentionally homeless, because we left the day before the bailfs came,” Roxanne said, as she fought back the tears. “They told us that there was nothing more they could do, and we would have to find our own privately rented accommodation, and pay for it with our housing benefit. “I spent weeks searching for somewhere to live. It was impossible. We didn’t have a guarantor.There is absolutely nowhere in Cornwall that will take a family of six on benefits in private rented accommodation,” she said.    The day came - October  - when Cornwall Council’s temporary accommodation ended, and the family were out on the streets again.For the second time, they made the trip back up the M.On Monday, October , they presented themselves again at  Temple Street, and were told that,  Bristol City Council had no duty to house them, they were Cornwall’s problem. In desperation the kids about to leave school and with nowhere to stay that night, they went to the offices of homeless charity Shelter. Shocked officials there immediately summoned their legal department, and a stf request threatening an emergency court appeal meant that Bristol City Council’s housing staff accepted that they could not, after all, leave a family of six, with four children under the age of eight, including a baby, on the streets. A housing officer used a corporate credit card to book an AirBnB.    They were told they would be staying three nights, and again on Thursday morning, were waiting at the council offices to be told where to go next. Finding them a place to live appears to have been handed over to Connolly  Callaghan, which runs a huge number of temporary accommodation units in Bristol. CC initially told them to go to a two-bed flat in Fishponds, but then told them it was flooded. After telling CC that their children’s school was in Bedminster, they were sent to a room in an HMO in Southville. “We arrived and the front door was open, the door to the room was open and we were told this was it,” said Roxanne. “There was blood stains on the bed. The kids walked in and sat down on the floor and I looked at the floor and it was filthy,” she added. “The state of the little bathroom was worse - one of my kids looked at it and refused to go in it - we go to Asda when he needs the loo.” The family have applied to be accepted onto the waiting list in Bristol.

story: NewsHorried campers saw woman trying to escape caravan before fatal clf plungeMum-of-three Elvira Ferraii died when her caravan was blown off a clf at Eco Beach Camping and Caravanning Park in Connemara, County GalwayShareCommentsByJohn FallonMilo Boyd:,  NOV NewsThe Swiss nurse tried but failed to get out of the falling caravan "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Mum-of-three Elvira Ferraii was staying at a remote beauty spot in County Galway when the violent Storm Ali battered Ireland and the UK with mph winds and heavy rain in September .Following a ferociously stormy night fellow camper Sally Forth got out of her tent at around .am on September  to spot Ms Ferrariaposs caravan sliding towards a clf edge, The Irish Mirror reported .She could see the Swiss woman desperately trying to get out of the mobile home through the open door before it disappeared over the clf edge.  Caleb-Amie Soltendieck, from Quebec in Canada, raced down to the beach after watching the vehicle fall  feet. He found the caravan partly submerged in water on top of Ms Ferrari’s body, which he managed to pull clear from the wreckage. Despite his attempts to resuscitate her it was immediately clear to Mr Soltendieck that she was dead, an inquest in Galway heard. Garda Shane Nally said the caravan was searched to checkanyone  was in it and that the body of Ms Ferrari was taken to University Hospital Galway for a post mortem. Her belongings, including a bicycle helmet, were scattered on the beach in the aftermath of the tragedy.    Although strong winds were predicted that day, the sheer strength of Storm Ali had taken those at the Eco Beach Camping and Caravanning Park in Connemara by surprise. The siteaposs owners Kris and Tatjama Acton had offered Ms Ferrari use of a mobile home in a more sheltered location night before the storm, which she had turned down.Coast Guard officer Michael Murray, who lives close to the camp site, said weather forecasters had underestimated the strength of the storm.He said: “The forecast was well off. It was near hurricane force, a severe storm.” Mr Murray added that he had to move his Toyota Landcruiser jeep, which he had parked close to where the caravan had been positioned, because it was being moved by the wind. Coroner Dr Ciaran MacLoughlin said the death was a tragic accident.    “There is no way this could have been foreseen, a storm of that nature is most unusual at that time of year, he told the court. The coroner said the wind swept the caravan away as Ms Ferrari tried to get out and that it came down on top of her on the beach, causing fatal injuries. Pathologist Dr Ramada Shatwan said that the cause of death was a severe traumatic head injury which led to a fractured skull and crushed brain tissue. He said there were no other fractured bones and that all organs were normal. Ms Ferrari lived in Steinmaur, a municipality north of Zurich, where she studied Alzheimeraposs disease.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen has posed for countless photograph and portraits during her time on the throne, but there was one particularly occasion which ended in a bit of drama. Back in  Annie Leibovitz was asked to take four official photos of the Monarch to celebrate the Queenaposs visit to the US. However confusion around the logistics meant it was reported that the Queen aposstormed outapos after clips from the shoot featured in the trailer for a BBC documentary. It later became known as Queengate and the BBC ended up apologising. However, the bad publicity around the shoot stayed with the Monarch and years later she decided she wanted to do something to fix things with Annie. Nine years after the photoshoot, the Queen sat down with her dressmaker and close friend Angela Kelly to discuss how they could make things right.    Writing in her new book The Other Side of the Coin, Angela explains what actually happened. She claims that the Queen was due to just meet Annie and her daughter, but when she arrived there were more than  people in the room. She simply didnapost have time to speak to them all, so left to go to the photo shoot as had always been the plan.    Angela writes: One of the good things about working in the same job for such a long time is that it allows you to put things right that havenapost quite gone as planned in the past. I have always felt so bad for Annie about how this was late reported, as she really didnapost deserve to be misrepresented in this way. So Angela suggested that the Queen ask Annie to take the official photos for her th birthday - and the Monarch loved the idea. The Queen was more than happy and in full agreement that it would be the right thing to do to make amends for the earlier misunderstanding, and she said yes. After they had discussed what they wanted from the official photos, Angela travelled to New York to personally ask Annieshe would take the pictures. When I told her that the Queen had asked for her toto photograph her on or close to her ninetieth birthday, Annie was thrilled and humbled to receive such an honour. Annie and her team flew to the UK over the Easter weekend to take the photos while the Royal Family were all together for the holiday. They took four photos which were shared around the world to mark the landmark birthday - with one of her with her great-grandchildren, including Prince George and Princess Charlotte, getting all of the attention.    There was also a photo of the Queen with her daughter Princess Anne, one of her with Prince Philip and another of her dressed down outside with her beloved corgis. Angela writes: The great-grandchildren were all so well behaved, and I think even they were excited about having a group photograph taken with the Queen. But th real stars of the show that day were the corgis. They knew how to work the camera, looking straight at Annie while she was taking the photos. The Queen was delighted with the pictures, which were very special family photos to be shared with the public.    Speaking about the incident back in , Annie said: The morning of the shoot the Queen came walking down the hall very purposely. She was definitely in force. This is all being taped by the BBC for a documentary. I would never have agreed to them being thereI felt I had any choice. But they had been following her around for months. There microphone picked up her saying: aposIaposve had enough of dressing like this thank you very muchapos, as she marched down the hall.    It appeared the Queen was stomping out of the photo session, rather than going into it, the photographer added. Leibovitz said the Queen was  minutes late as she had to get into the complicated ceremonial outfit for the pictures. Once the Queen was in position Leibovitz asked to take off her crown. She said: I asked hershe would remove the tiara, I said it looked a little dressy.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum was so anxious about driving that she thought bridges would collapse on her and sheaposd be stuck in a traffic jam forever. Nicola Ward says she would catastrophise about ious situations that could happen to her while she was in her car.  The -year-old said she would feel like Iaposm in turmoil when in the car and that driving would leave her feeling absolutely exhausted.  The small business owner from Reading noticed her driving anxiety started when she moved out of London and away from city le to the suburbs, to start a family. She drives on a daily basis but since the birth of her daughter, Sydney, her anxiety in the car has signicantly increased and says sheaposs always ‘on high alert’ whilst driving. Nicola admits she does not trust other motorists to follow the highway code and panics when she gets stuck in traffic.  She told Mirror: I need my car on a daily basis to get to work and for childcare so itaposs not something I can stop doing. I always feel most vulnerable when my baby is in the car. Things got worse after I had a collision in Spring  when someone drove into me. After that I was extremely jumpy in the car. I started noticing and envisioning things happening and I would catastrophise situations. I would look in my rear view mirror and was certain that someone would drive into the back of me.   Iaposd have extreme thoughts like I would be driving under a bridge and I would be terried it would collapse. If I was stuck in traffic I would be extremely worried that Iaposd never get out of the jam and would plan my escape route. I was feeling constantly on edge while driving. I was unsettled and could never relax. I just wanted to get to where I was going.    Nicola shared her experience as it was revealed nearly a third of UK drivers have suffered a near miss on the roads due to feelings of anxiety, according to new research commissioned by ST CENTRAL Insurance and leading mental health charity, SANE. As many as  of us have experienced anxiety while driving, putting themselves and other drivers at risk. The research forms part of a new joint campaign launched earlier this month dedicated to raising awareness of anxiety and the threat it presents on our roads. SANE has also developed a suite of practical advice to address this problem, by helping motorists tackle feelings of anxiety. To help address this issue and improve driver safety, ST CENTRAL has partnered with SANE to provide advice for how drivers might tackle feelings of anxiousness both before and during driving: .     Before the journey ask yourself: are you safe to drive  Consider whether it’s worth taking the journey at all. If you must travel, could you take public transport instead, or call a taxi  .     Pull over and stop at the earliest and safest opportunity. If you begin to feel anxious while driving, breathing exercises and meditation techniques can help ease the feelings of anxiety once safely stopped. .     Be mindful of noise. Don’t be afraid to ask passengers to keep the noise down. If you listen to music, consider opting for songs with a lower tempo, or music you find calming. .     Think about your environment. Keeping the car clean and tidy could help create a calm atmosphere. You could consider putting lavender, which can be soothing, in their car to create a relaxed atmosphere. .     If you’re a passenger, and you feel unsafe due to a driver that appears to be feeling anxious, consider gently suggesting stopping for a toilet break or for a soft drink. De-escalation is important, because getting into an argument with the driver could make the situation worse.
